unnormalised: So, someone asked how much veggies people in India actually buy on average, right? Well, it totally depends! Like, if you're in a big city like Mumbai or Delhi, and you’re going to Reliance Fresh or D-Mart, you might be buying stuff in kgs. Think 1 kg of potatoes, 500 gms of tomatoes, maybe ½ kg of onions. It adds up fast, especially if you’re cooking for a family.
normalised: So, someone asked how much veggies people in India actually buy on average, right? Well, it totally depends! Like, if you're in a big city like Mumbai or Delhi, and you’re going to Reliance Fresh or D-Mart, you might be buying stuff in kilograms. Think one kilogram of potatoes, five hundred grams of tomatoes, maybe half a kilogram of onions. It adds up fast, especially if you’re cooking for a family.

unnormalised: And then there's the price thing. The cost of veggies changes all the time! One week, tomatoes are ₹20/kg, the next they’re ₹80/kg! It’s crazy, right? So, how much you buy also depends on your budget. No one's going to buy 2 kgs of tomatoes if they’re super expensive!

unnormalised: But if you’re living in a smaller town, things are different. You might be buying veggies from the local sabzi mandi. Here, they might measure things out in "pao," which is like 250 gms. So, you might say, "Ek pao bhindi dena," which means give me 250 gms of okra. Or "Adha kilo gobi," meaning half a kilo of cauliflower.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on buying fruits! You go to a fruit vendor and ask for a dozen bananas. That’s 12 bananas. Or maybe you want a kilo of mangoes when they're in season.
